verses.text: Does not humanity have hard service on earth, and are not their days like those of a hired laborer?
verses.comment: Job compares human life to that of a hired man, marked by toil and suffering, showing the universality of human struggle—a theme echoed in Ecclesiastes 1:2-3.

verses.text: Like a slave longing for the shade, and like a hired servant waiting for his wages,
verses.comment: The longing for rest and reward prefigures the hope for eternal rest and the fulfillment found in Christ (cf. Heb. 4:9-10).

verses.text: So I am allotted months of emptiness, and nights of misery are assigned to me.
verses.comment: Job’s lament highlights the experience of suffering over a prolonged period, a common experience for those enduring trial.

verses.text: When I lie down I say, 'When shall I arise?' But the night drags on, and I am full of restlessness until dawn.
verses.comment: Recalls Psalm 6:6, expressing despair and sleeplessness in the midst of suffering—a universal cry of the human heart.

verses.text: My flesh is clothed with worms and scabs; my skin is broken and festering.
verses.comment: Describes Job's physical affliction, underlining the reality of bodily suffering and the limits of human strength.

verses.text: My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle and come to an end without hope.
verses.comment: Job’s view of life’s brevity and seeming hopelessness is shared by the psalmist (Ps. 39:5), foreshadowing the longing for redemption.

verses.text: Remember that my life is a mere breath; my eye will never again see good.
verses.comment: Affirms human frailty, echoing themes of fleeting life and mortality found throughout Scripture (see Ps. 39:5, Jas. 4:14).

verses.text: The eye of him who sees me will see me no longer; while your eyes are on me, I shall no longer be.
verses.comment: This expresses Job’s sense of impending death; he sees himself as disappearing from the notice of man and God.

verses.text: As a cloud fades and vanishes, so he who goes down to the grave does not come up;
verses.comment: Job’s comparison of human life to a vanishing cloud is repeated in Psalm 103:16, emphasizing the transient nature of existence.

verses.text: he returns no more to his house, nor does his place know him anymore.
verses.comment: Reinforces the finality of death and separation from earthly life, a theme developed further in Ecclesiastes 9:5.

verses.text: Therefore I will not restrain my mouth; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
verses.comment: Job’s honesty in prayer anticipates the anguish of Jesus in Gethsemane (Matt. 26:38), showing the value in expressing sorrow before God.

verses.text: Am I the sea, or a sea monster, that you set a guard over me?
verses.comment: Job uses mythological language to question God’s treatment, anticipating God’s response in chapters 38–41. The sea often symbolizes chaos God must restrain.

verses.text: When I say, 'My bed will comfort me, my couch will ease my complaint,'
verses.comment: Even the hope of rest is denied Job, foreshadowing the spiritual reality that true rest is ultimately found in God (see Matt. 11:28).

verses.text: you frighten me with dreams and terrify me with visions,
verses.comment: This verse resonates with the experience of spiritual trial, where even sleep is restless—a precursor to New Testament struggles with spiritual darkness.

verses.text: so that I choose strangling and death rather than my bones.
verses.comment: Job’s desperation articulates a longing for escape; still, such suffering can prepare the heart for surrender and hope in resurrection (see 2 Cor. 1:9).

verses.text: I loathe my life; I would not live forever. Leave me alone, for my days are but a breath.
verses.comment: Echoes the realization of life’s brevity and the insufficiency of earthly existence—a longing ultimately fulfilled in the life to come.

verses.text: What is man, that you make so much of him, and that you set your heart on him,
verses.comment: Job’s question is answered more fully in the incarnation, when God’s love for mankind is revealed in Christ (Heb. 2:6–9).

verses.text: visit him every morning and test him every moment?
verses.comment: God’s attentiveness can feel like scrutiny, yet in the fullness of revelation, God’s discipline is understood as loving formation for eternal life (Heb. 12:7).

verses.text: How long will you not look away from me, nor leave me alone till I swallow my spit?
verses.comment: Job’s plea for relief is echoed by many saints who endure trial, but those who persevere are assured of reward (Jas. 1:12).

verses.text: If I have sinned, what have I done to you, O watcher of men? Why have you made me your target? Have I become a burden to you?
verses.comment: Job’s questioning brings up the problem of suffering and divine justice. The ultimate answer is found in the mystery of Christ’s suffering for our sake (1 Pet. 2:24).

verses.text: Why do you not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity? For now I shall sleep in the dust; you will seek me, but I shall not be.
verses.comment: Here, Job longs for both forgiveness and reconciliation—answered in the ministry of Jesus, who brings true pardon and resurrection hope (Mark 2:10, John 11:25–26).
